utterances: I think at this point, everyone agrees that it has become a crisis, not only for animals but also for humans as well.
Today she's headed to a construction site just off the highway.
It's also home to a pair of dogs she's hoping to coax into her SUV.
(SOUNDBITE OF WHISTLING)
The 50-pound female walks right up to Tarashevska, happy to get a snack.
In a few minutes, the shepherd-pit bull mix has been corralled and is resting on a sleeping bag in the back of her vehicle.
The male is too skittish, so she sets a trap and leaves.
Tarashevska is used to seeing the worst.
So is Dallas City Council Member Tiffinni Young.
It is an epidemic.
It is out of control.
Stray dogs are everywhere.
Young represents this part of Dallas, just south and east of downtown.
She's a fierce critic of how the stray problem has been handled.
She wants more code enforcement so dogs can't escape through shoddy fences.
She calls for mandatory microchipping and real consequences when pet owners fail to follow the rules.
There's some point you begin to lose those rights to own those animals when you're not taking care of the animals, when you are allowing them to roam the streets and terrorize others.
Jody Jones, who runs Animal Services, admits the stray problem in Dallas is bigger than it should be.
Dylan Blaylock is a spokesman for a watchdog group called the Government Accountability Project.
Rosenzweig says most Chinese people aren't motivated to jump through the government's hoops to get more political information, so they are sympathetic to the government's position on Tibet.
And as an example, he points to a recent concert in China by the singer, Bjork, when she shouted, free Tibet from the stage, her Chinese audience was insulted.
Laura Sydell, NPR News.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Some of the latest clues about Abu Musab al-Zarqawi come from people who claim to speak for him.
According to a Web site that says it represents al-Qaeda in Iraq, he's been wounded.
The Jordanian-born militant is described by Americans as Osama bin Laden's chief operator in Iraq and the most wanted man in the country.
A man described as a Zarqawi aide gave some more information about him to The Washington Post, and joining us now is Post bureau chief Ellen Knickmeyer.
And, Ellen, first, who is this aide to Zarqawi and what did he say?

Well, we talked to some of the fighters and some of the higher-ranking people with Zarqawi's al-Qaeda in Iraq group after the Web site came out and they said that Zarqawi was shot somewhere between the shoulder and the chest in what Lieutenant Abu Karrar said was an ambush Saturday to Sunday by US and Iraqi forces.
And they said the location of this ambush, somewhere around Ramadi, which is in western Iraq, in the province that's caused the most trouble for the Americans, and that surprised me.
Why would people associated with Zarqawi be willing to say approximately where he is or at least where he was?
Well, I guess that was where it happened, but we don't know where he--they claim he is right now.
They say that he's in a safe place being treated by foreign doctors right now.

And, you know, this is a message that, for whatever reason, al-Qaeda in Iraq has chosen to put out, and it's a consistent one, but just because it's consistent doesn't necessarily mean that that's actually what's happened to Zarqawi.
How can you feel confident that this person who represents himself as an aide to Zarqawi is who he says he is and that what he says is true?
We have contacts with insurgents.
I mean, the journalists, some of whom have grown up in these towns, know who are the insurgents and know who the other people are.
And we know that Zarqawi's people are operating in that area.
The people that we're talking to from the fighters to the other officers, they're all putting out a consistent message.
So according to Zarqawi's people, in any event, how seriously wounded is he?
They said he lost consciousness a couple of times after his wound.
They say that he is helping his lieutenant pick out a successor in case he dies.
Is the name of some successor known?
What we were hearing was that there were four possible people that were being considered.
Three of them were Arab and one of them was Iraqi.
I don't know that they've come forward with any name of new people, the person they claim is going to succeed him.
Now this is a man that Americans have focused on extensively.
And when you talk about a successor, it does raise the question of what would happen to the Iraqi insurgency if Zarqawi were out of the picture.

The American military says that while he's, like, the poster child of the insurgency, if you have it, that--I mean, it's like a hydra-headed insurgency, and if he dies that doesn't at all mean that their fight is over.
Ellen, at the same time this news about Zarqawi has come out, the US military has begun another offensive, we're told, in western Iraq.
And this is a piece of countryside that you know well because you reported on the last US military offensive a few weeks ago there.
What do you know about what's happening in that part of the country?
This morning there was a new offensive that seems to target the town of Haditha.
It's in an area along the Euphrates River where US troops have met resistance before and they've come under attack.

And the US military believes that foreign fighters, in particular, are operating all along the Euphrates River and using these towns as kind of a channel for money and for fighters and for arms, and it sounds like they've just kind of cordoned off the town and they're going house to house seeing what they're going to roust up.
You reported that there was evidence that insurgents were able to escape some villages before the US military got there in the last offensive.
Is there any indication that the US military learned from that experience?
The local people did say that a lot of the foreign fighters slipped out through Syria, that they had enough advanced notice.
And also some of them said that some of the Marines lifted a blocking position that a lot of foreign fighters ran out.
The fact that they're--the Marines are going back so quickly after just a week, this tells me that they're trying to stay on the offensive.
Ellen Knickmeyer is a reporter for The Washington Post.
She's in Baghdad.
Ellen, thanks very much.
You're welcome.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Joni Mitchell didn't produce an album of new songs for nearly 10 years.
Stories and rumors abounded about the reasons - she was fed up with the record industry, she was losing her voice.
But in a burst of activity over the last 12 months, she's collaborated on a ballet.
She's opened an exhibition of her artwork.
And she's released that long-awaited CD.
Reese Erlich spent some time with Joni Mitchell as she worked on her art show in New York.
He has this report.
A year later, it happened again.
To this point, she's making $193,000.
Tax-free.
Of course, in the past, the U.S.
had said that the Iranians are responsible for training and supplying militias with guns and weapons, and particularly those roadside bombs that have been responsible for so many deaths.

He did, however, go on to say that they all have now agreed for this trilateral security subcommittee aimed at bringing some kind of stability to Iraq, something that people here hear all the time but really see no concrete results on the ground.

So there's actually going to be a committee and there will be some Iranian representatives, where, there in Baghdad, and some Americans and some Iraqis, and they'll all sit together and talk about what to do?
Well, apparently so.
I mean, Ambassador Crocker said that they would iron out the details over the next few days, but I think we have to reiterate just how rare this meeting was.
It's only the second time the U.S.
and Iran have sat down together since 1980.
So it is quite an achievement in those terms and given that the relations have been so strained.
Ambassador Crocker said, I want to see this measured in results, not principles and promises.
They have really laid the law down to the Iranians.
The Iranians, of course, denying they've got anything to do with these attacks.
But they did seem to make some progress.
The meeting did go on for a lot longer than the last one at the end of May here in Baghdad so there is some hope.
But of course those words peace and security and stability are something the Iraqis on the ground hear all the time, and yet the death and devastation and the daily attacks just go on and on.
You know, the Iranians are notably Shia Muslims and these are Shia militias that seem to be the main focus of the U.S.
surge in Baghdad, the attempts to control security now.
What is the factor there?
Well, I mean, you really can't leave - the whole thing about being here in Baghdad and the situation is you can't really put it down to any one fraction.
Yes, there were Shia militias.
Yes, there are Sunni insurgents.
But there are also criminal gangs operating here.
Kidnappings happen on a daily basis.
Bodies are fished out from the river and found all over the city.
It's really not any one group you can blame for the violence.
Political analysts in Baghdad, how do they explain the participation of Iran in this?
Why is Iran getting into these talks?
Well, you have to look at the situation historically here in Iraq.
It was a Sunni minority that were in control before.
The government is now dominated by Shias, and there's a great deal of connection between the Shias here in Iraq and the Shias in Iran.
It's a Shia country.
And I think they can see an opportunity to play a role with the government here in Iraq and form some kind of basis of power, something that probably would worry the U.S.
a great deal.
The BBC's Andy Gallagher with us from Baghdad.
Andy, thank you.
Thank you.
There are more than 1,300 coal mines in the US, according to the Department of Energy, and no doubt the topic on the mind of everyone who works in them is what happened at the Sago mine.
I spoke earlier with Thomas Stern(ph).
He works at a coal mine in Cameron, West Virginia, about two hours north of Tallmansville.
